channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: ‘It Had to Be Stopped’: Heroes Rise Amid France Terror Attacks
item.media:description: Franck, second from left, and Gwenaël Leriche, left, were awarded medals by the City of Nice, France, for trying to stop a terrorist whose cargo truck ran over scores of people there during a Bastille Day celebration.
item.media:credit: Bertrand Langlois/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Some ordinary people in France have reacted heroically, risking their lives by fighting terrorists when they found themselves in the midst of an attack.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Without Britain, European Leaders Chart a Rocky New Course
item.media:description: Prime Minister Matteo Renzi of Italy, left, with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President François Hollande of France on Monday on Ventotene, an Italian island west of Naples in the Tyrrhenian Sea.
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Carlo Hermann
item.description: The politically vulnerable leaders of Germany, France and Italy met to discuss the European Union’s new direction after Britain’s vote to leave the bloc.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: U.N. Relief Official Calls Crisis in Aleppo the ‘Apex of Horror’
item.media:description: Search and rescue workers carried an injured man after government airstrikes hit a neighborhood in Aleppo, Syria, last month.
item.media:credit: Beha el Halebi/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of Syrians are in dire need of aid, with the situation especially acute in Aleppo, but the official said not a single relief convoy had been dispatched so far in August.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Iran Revokes Russia’s Use of Air Base, Saying Moscow ‘Betrayed Trust’
item.media:description: A Russian Tu-22M3 bomber during an airstrike over Syria last week.
item.media:credit: Russian Defense Ministry Press Service, via Associated Press
item.description: Tehran has stopped allowing Russian planes to fly into Syria from one of its bases, complaining that the Kremlin has been too public about the deal.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Japan, Seeking to Regain Manufacturing Might, Bets on Aerospace
item.media:description: The Mitsubishi Regional Jet, now expected in late 2018, is being billed as an instrument of national pride and industrial renewal.
item.media:credit: Toshifumi Kitamura/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The Mitsubishi Regional Jet has become a symbol of national pride and industrial renewal, but it is plagued by delays and cost overruns.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Nearly 1,800 Killed in Duterte’s Drug War, Philippine Police Official Tells Senators
item.media:description: A crime scene in Tondo, near Manila, on Friday. President Rodrigo Duterte has pledged to rid the country of drug dealers.
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.description: Under President Rodrigo Duterte, 712 suspects have died in police operations and 1,067 have been killed by vigilantes, the nation’s police chief says.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR and RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Hong Kong Journal: Exit the Dragon? Kung Fu, Once Central to Hong Kong Life, Is Waning
item.media:description: Mak Che Kong, a kung fu master, giving a lesson in a park in the Kowloon section of Hong Kong. He had to shut his studio when his rent soared.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: The kung fu culture that Bruce Lee helped popularize — and that gave the city a gritty, exotic image in the eyes of foreigners — is in decline.
item.dc:creator: CHARLOTTE YANG

item.title: John Kerry Calls for Speedy Deployment of South Sudan Protection Force
item.description: Mr. Kerry made the remarks during a trip to Africa and the Middle East, which Kenyan newspapers have described as a “peace mission.”
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Extremist Pleads Guilty in Hague Court to Destroying Cultural Sites in Timbuktu
item.media:description: A still image from a video, taken in 2012, of Islamist militants destroying an ancient shrine in Timbuktu, Mali.
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Ahmad al-Faqi al-Mahdi, a member of a Qaeda-linked group, was a defendant in the International Criminal Court’s first prosecution of destruction of cultural heritage as a war crime.
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: What’s Next for the New York Subway? Toronto Already Knows
item.media:description: Riders on a so-called open gangway train in Toronto this month. The spacious cars were introduced nearly five years ago.
item.media:credit: J. Adam Huggins for The New York Times
item.description: Nearly five years after Canada’s largest city introduced so-called open gangway trains, riders have given the trains a ringing endorsement. Now officials in New York are embracing the design.
item.dc:creator: EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS

item.title: With Crocodiles in Custody, Police in Humpty Doo, Australia, Seek Human Accomplices
item.description: The police are searching for men who threw reptiles into a school office in the town of Humpty Doo before a break-in.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Britain’s Huge Investment in Summer Olympic Sports Pays Off
item.media:description: The cyclist Callum Skinner of Britain after a gold medal in the team sprint on Aug. 11 at the Rio Games.
item.media:credit: Greg Baker/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: By focusing on sports that offer the best and most medal prospects, Britain won 27 gold medals at the Rio Games, a huge improvement from the one it won at the 1996 Atlanta Games.
item.dc:creator: TIM WIGMORE

item.title: Britain Moves to Separate Radicalized Inmates From Other Prisoners
item.media:description: Anjem Choudary
item.media:credit: Adrian Dennis/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The change comes amid rising concern across Europe about the influence of Islamist ideologues in prisons.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Report Accuses Mexico’s President of Plagiarism in Law School Thesis
item.media:description: President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico in July. A report by an investigative journalist said he plagiarized nearly a third of his thesis in law school.
item.media:credit: Mariana Bazo/Reuters
item.description: An investigative journalist cited findings by a group of specialists and academics who reviewed President Enrique Peña Nieto’s 1991 thesis.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Sinosphere: Firing of Teacher Battling Cancer Prompts an Outcry in China
item.description: After her university dismissed her for absenteeism after she was treated for ovarian cancer, Liu Lingli began selling clothes on the street to pay her medical bills.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Letter From Europe: The Multifaceted ‘Burkini’ Debate
item.media:description: A woman wearing a “burkini” on Friday on a beach in Marseille, France.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: Heated discussions over Islamic women’s wear are not limited to France. And the arguments – for and against – run the gamut of reasoning.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: Fake ISIS Attack in Prague, Intended as Protest, Causes Panic
item.media:description: A stunt in Prague on Sunday stirred panic among tourists who thought a terrorist attack was underway.
item.media:credit: Marketa Horesovska/Czech News Agency, via Associated Press
item.description: A stunt by an anti-immigration activist sent tourists running for cover, knocking over chairs at restaurants.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and JAN RICHTER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Toots Thielemans, Jazz Harmonica Player, Is Dead at 94
item.media:description: Mr. Thielemans, right, and Benny Goodman play each other’s instruments around 1948. Mr. Thielemans toured with Goodman’s big band.
item.media:credit: Metronome, via Getty Images
item.description: The Belgian-American also developed a signature style by playing a guitar and whistling in unison, and his music has been part of the “Sesame Street” theme song.
item.dc:creator: PETER KEEPNEWS

item.title: A Morning Surprise for Japan: Shinzo Abe as Super Mario
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, whose capital, Tokyo, will host the 2020 Summer Games, appeared as Super Mario during the Olympic closing ceremony in Rio de Janeiro.
item.media:credit: Stoyan Nenov/Reuters
item.description: Reaction on social media was swift and amused when the normally dry prime minister popped out of a pipe at the closing ceremony of the Rio Games.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: What in the World: The Song in the Heart of Many Chinese Comes From Insects
item.media:description: Katydids for sale this month at a market in Beijing.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Chirping bugs like katydids, cicadas and crickets are prized as pets and are ingrained in the culture.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: What in the World: Here’s a New Angle on the Shape of the World
item.media:credit: Maziyar Pahlevan
item.description: An Australian statistician has devised a method to rank the world’s nations by how rectangular they are, with Egypt at the head of the class.
item.dc:creator: JAKE DOHERTY

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: My Daughter the Pole
item.media:description: Young people protested Britain’s vote to leave the European Union in London last month.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: History comes full circle for one young woman at a time when the world needs moral clarity to save it from darkness.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Can Thailand Really Hide a Rebellion?
item.media:description: Inspecting the scene of a bomb explosion this month in Hua Hin, Thailand. Coordinated bombings and arson attacks in tourist destinations over two days killed four people and injured 35.
item.media:credit: Rungroj Yongrit/European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: When bombs go off, the generals won’t admit the presence of — or deal with — rebels in the country’s south.
item.dc:creator: MATT WHEELER

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Can Leicester Do It Again?
item.media:description: Claudio Ranieri, the Leicester City F.C. manager, knows he has another tough season ahead of him. ‘‘I’m the underdog. Always will be. And I love it,’’ he said.
item.media:credit: Ringo Chiu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The Cinderella of English soccer — and its indefatigable Italian coach — reveal everything that’s great about modern Europe.
item.dc:creator: BEPPE SEVERGNINI

item.title: Nigeria Is Freeing Children From Boko Haram, Then Locking Them Up
item.media:description: Displaced people taking shelter from the rain at a camp in Maiduguri, Nigeria, in June.
item.media:credit: Jane Hahn for The New York Times
item.description: Civilians, and even infants, are ending up in military detention centers as Nigeria holds people it suspects of being sympathizers of the Islamist extremist group.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: A Foreign Correspondent’s Day at the Beach
item.media:description: Tourists at a beach in Tulum.
item.media:credit: Reinhard Dirscherl/ullstein bild, via Getty Images
item.description: Even in the wildly popular beach town of Tulum on the Yucatán Peninsula, menace can lurk just beneath the surface.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Skala Sikaminias Journal: Greek Villagers Rescued Migrants. Now They Are the Ones Suffering.
item.media:description: The keeper of the main church in Skala Sikaminias, Lesbos, looked out to sea. Some villagers say that when they look at the horizon, they often think that another refugee boat is coming.
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.description: The island of Lesbos was ground zero for refugees flooding across the Aegean. A year later, the imprint of that experience still affects one village that tried to help.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.media:credit: Candace Feit
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
